content: 'Security Management Subnets - Mechanisms exist to implement security management subnets to isolate security tools and support components from other internal system components by implementing separate subnetworks with managed interfaces to other components of the system.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization implement security management subnets to isolate security tools and support components from other internal system components by implementing separate subnetworks with managed interfaces to other components of the system?'

label: NET-06.2
content: 'Virtual Local Area Network (VLAN) Separation - Mechanisms exist to enable Virtual Local Area Networks (VLANs) to limit the ability of devices on a network to directly communicate with other devices on the subnet and limit an attacker's ability to laterally move to compromise neighboring systems.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization enable Virtual Local Area Networks (VLANs) to limit the ability of devices on a network to directly communicate with other devices on the subnet and limit an attacker's ability to laterally move to compromise neighboring systems?'

label: NET-06.3
content: 'Sensitive / Regulated Data Enclave (Secure Zone) - Mechanisms exist to implement segmentation controls to restrict inbound and outbound connectivity for sensitive / regulated data enclaves (secure zones).; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization implement segmentation controls to restrict inbound and outbound connectivity for sensitive / regulated data enclaves (secure zones)?'

label: NET-06.4
content: 'Segregation From Enterprise Services - Mechanisms exist to isolate sensitive / regulated data enclaves (secure zones) from corporate-provided IT resources by providing enclave-specific IT services (e.g., directory services, DNS, NTP, ITAM, antimalware, patch management, etc.) to those isolated network segments.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization isolate sensitive / regulated data enclaves (secure zones) from corporate-provided IT resources by providing enclave-specific IT services (e.g., directory services, DNS, NTP, ITAM, antimalware, patch management, etc.) to those isolated network segments?'

label: NET-06.5
content: 'Direct Internet Access Restrictions - Mechanisms exist to prohibit, or strictly-control, Internet access from sensitive / regulated data enclaves (secure zones).; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization prohibit, or strictly-control, Internet access from sensitive / regulated data enclaves (secure zones)?'

label: NET-06.6
content: 'Microsegmentation - Automated mechanisms exist to enable microsegmentation, either physically or virtually, to divide the network according to application and data workflows communications needs.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to enable microsegmentation, either physically or virtually, to divide the network according to application and data workflows communications needs?'

label: NET-06.7
content: 'Software Defined Networking (SDN) - Automated mechanisms exist to enable dynamic, policy-driven network segmentation, access controls and traffic management with a Software Defined Networking (SDN) architecture.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization enable dynamic, policy-driven network segmentation, access controls and traffic management?'

label: NET-07
content: 'Network Connection Termination - Mechanisms exist to terminate network connections at the end of a session or after an organization-defined time period of inactivity.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization terminate network connections at the end of a session or after an organization-defined time period of inactivity?'

label: NET-08
content: 'Network Intrusion Detection / Prevention Systems (NIDS / NIPS) - Mechanisms exist to employ Network Intrusion Detection / Prevention Systems (NIDS/NIPS) to detect and/or prevent intrusions into the network.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization employ Network Intrusion Detection / Prevention Systems (NIDS/NIPS) to detect and/or prevent intrusions into the network?'

label: NET-08.1
content: 'DMZ Networks - Mechanisms exist to monitor De-Militarized Zone (DMZ) network segments to separate untrusted networks from trusted networks.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization monitor De-Militarized Zone (DMZ) network segments to separate untrusted networks from trusted networks?'

label: NET-08.2
content: 'Wireless Intrusion Detection / Prevention Systems (WIDS / WIPS) - Mechanisms exist to monitor wireless network segments to implement Wireless Intrusion Detection / Prevention Systems (WIDS/WIPS) technologies.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization monitor wireless network segments to implement Wireless Intrusion Detection / Prevention Systems (WIDS/WIPS) technologies?'

label: NET-08.3
content: 'Host Containment - Automated mechanisms exist to enforce host containment protections that revoke or quarantine a host’s access to the network.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to enforce host containment protections that revoke or quarantine a host’s access to the network?'

label: NET-08.4
content: 'Resource Containment - Automated mechanisms exist to enforce resource containment protections that remove or quarantine a resource’s access to other resources.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to enforce resource containment protections that remove or quarantine a resource’s access to other resources?'

label: NET-09
content: 'Session Integrity - Mechanisms exist to protect the authenticity and integrity of communications sessions.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization protect the authenticity and integrity of communications sessions?'

label: NET-09.1
content: 'Invalidate Session Identifiers at Logout - Automated mechanisms exist to invalidate session identifiers upon user logout or other session termination.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to invalidate session identifiers upon user logout or other session termination?'

label: NET-09.2
content: 'Unique System-Generated Session Identifiers - Automated mechanisms exist to generate and recognize unique session identifiers for each session.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to generate and recognize unique session identifiers for each session?'

label: NET-10
content: 'Domain Name Service (DNS) Resolution - Mechanisms exist to ensure Domain Name Service (DNS) resolution is designed, implemented and managed to protect the security of name / address resolution.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization ensure Domain Name Service (DNS) resolution is designed, implemented and managed to protect the security of name / address resolution?'

label: NET-10.1
content: 'Architecture & Provisioning for Name / Address Resolution Service - Mechanisms exist to ensure systems that collectively provide Domain Name Service (DNS) resolution service are fault-tolerant and implement internal/external role separation.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization ensure systems that collectively provide Domain Name Service (DNS) resolution service are fault-tolerant and implement internal/external role separation?'

label: NET-10.2
content: 'Secure Name / Address Resolution Service (Recursive or Caching Resolver) - Mechanisms exist to perform data origin authentication and data integrity verification on the Domain Name Service (DNS) resolution responses received from authoritative sources when requested by client systems.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization perform data origin authentication and data integrity verification on the Domain Name Service (DNS) resolution responses received from authoritative sources when requested by client systems?'

label: NET-10.3
content: 'Sender Policy Framework (SPF) - Mechanisms exist to validate the legitimacy of email communications through configuring a Domain Naming Service (DNS) Sender Policy Framework (SPF) record to specify the IP addresses and/or hostnames that are authorized to send email from the specified domain.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization validate the legitimacy of email communications through configuring a Domain Naming Service (DNS) Sender Policy Framework (SPF) record to specify the IP addresses and/or hostnames that are authorized to send email from the specified domain?'

label: NET-10.4
content: 'Domain Registrar Security - Mechanisms exist to lock the domain name registrar to prevent a denial of service caused by unauthorized deletion, transfer or other unauthorized modification of a domain’s registration details.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization lock the domain name registrar to prevent a denial of service caused by unauthorized deletion, transfer or other unauthorized modification of a domain’s registration details?'

label: NET-11
content: 'Out-of-Band Channels - Mechanisms exist to utilize out-of-band channels for the electronic transmission of information and/or the physical shipment of system components or devices to authorized individuals.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization utilize out-of-band channels for the electronic transmission of information and/or the physical shipment of system components or devices to authorized individuals?'

label: NET-12
content: 'Safeguarding Data Over Open Networks - Cryptographic mechanisms exist to implement strong cryptography and security protocols to safeguard sensitive/regulated data during transmission over open, public networks.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Are cryptographic mechanisms utilized to implement strong cryptography and security protocols to safeguard sensitive/regulated data during transmission over open, public networks?'

label: NET-12.1
content: 'Wireless Link Protection - Mechanisms exist to protect external and internal wireless links from signal parameter attacks through monitoring for unauthorized wireless connections, including scanning for unauthorized wireless access points and taking appropriate action, if an unauthorized connection is discovered.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization protect external and internal wireless links from signal parameter attacks through monitoring for unauthorized wireless connections, including scanning for unauthorized wireless access points and taking appropriate action, if an unauthorized connection is discovered?'

label: NET-12.2
content: 'End-User Messaging Technologies - Mechanisms exist to prohibit the transmission of unprotected sensitive/regulated data by end-user messaging technologies.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization prohibit the transmission of unprotected sensitive/regulated data by end-user messaging technologies?'

label: NET-13
content: 'Electronic Messaging - Mechanisms exist to protect the confidentiality, integrity and availability of electronic messaging communications.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization protect the confidentiality, integrity and availability of electronic messaging communications?'

label: NET-14
content: 'Remote Access - Mechanisms exist to define, control and review organization-approved, secure remote access methods.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization define, control and review organization-approved, secure remote access methods?'

label: NET-14.1
content: 'Automated Monitoring & Control - Automated mechanisms exist to monitor and control remote access sessions.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to monitor and control remote access sessions?'

label: NET-14.2
content: 'Protection of Confidentiality / Integrity Using Encryption - Cryptographic mechanisms exist to protect the confidentiality and integrity of remote access sessions (e.g., VPN).; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Are cryptographic mechanisms utilized to protect the confidentiality and integrity of remote access sessions (e.g., VPN)?'

label: NET-14.3
content: 'Managed Access Control Points - Mechanisms exist to route all remote accesses through managed network access control points (e.g., VPN concentrator).; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization route all remote accesses through managed network access control points (e.g., VPN concentrator)?'

label: NET-14.4
content: 'Remote Privileged Commands & Sensitive Data Access - Mechanisms exist to restrict the execution of privileged commands and access to security-relevant information via remote access only for compelling operational needs.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization restrict the execution of privileged commands and access to security-relevant information via remote access only for compelling operational needs?'

label: NET-14.5
content: 'Work From Anywhere (WFA) - Telecommuting Security - Mechanisms exist to define secure telecommuting practices and govern remote access to systems and data for remote workers.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization define secure telecommuting practices and govern remote access to systems and data for remote workers?'

label: NET-14.6
content: 'Third-Party Remote Access Governance - Mechanisms exist to proactively control and monitor third-party accounts used to access, support, or maintain system components via remote access.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization proactively control and monitor third-party accounts used to access, support, or maintain system components via remote access?'

label: NET-14.7
content: 'Endpoint Security Validation - Automated mechanisms exist to validate the security posture of the endpoint devices (e.g., software versions, patch levels, etc.) prior to allowing devices to connect to organizational technology assets.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization validate the security posture of the endpoint devices (e.g., software versions, patch levels, etc.) prior to allowing devices to connect to organizational technology assets?'

label: NET-14.8
content: 'Expeditious Disconnect / Disable Capability - Mechanisms exist to provide the capability to expeditiously disconnect or disable a user's remote access session.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization provide the capability to expeditiously disconnect or disable a user's remote access session?'

label: NET-15
content: 'Wireless Networking - Mechanisms exist to control authorized wireless usage and monitor for unauthorized wireless access.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization control authorized wireless usage and monitor for unauthorized wireless access?'

label: NET-15.1
content:
'Authentication & Encryption - Mechanisms exist to secure Wi-Fi (e.g., IEEE 802.11) and prevent unauthorized access by:
 (1) Authenticating devices trying to connect; and 
 (2) Encrypting transmitted data.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization secure Wi-Fi (e.g., IEEE 802.11) and prevent unauthorized access by:
 (1) Authenticating devices trying to connect; and 
 (2) Encrypting transmitted data?'

label: NET-15.2
content: 'Disable Wireless Networking - Mechanisms exist to disable unnecessary wireless networking capabilities that are internally embedded within system components prior to issuance to end users.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization disable unnecessary wireless networking capabilities that are internally embedded within system components prior to issuance to end users?'

label: NET-15.3
content: 'Restrict Configuration By Users - Mechanisms exist to identify and explicitly authorize users who are allowed to independently configure wireless networking capabilities.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization identify and explicitly authorize users who are allowed to independently configure wireless networking capabilities?'

label: NET-15.4
content: 'Wireless Boundaries - Mechanisms exist to confine wireless communications to organization-controlled boundaries.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization confine wireless communications to organization-controlled boundaries?'

label: NET-15.5
content: 'Rogue Wireless Detection - Mechanisms exist to test for the presence of Wireless Access Points (WAPs) and identify all authorized and unauthorized WAPs within the facility(ies).; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization test for the presence of Wireless Access Points (WAPs) and identify all authorized and unauthorized WAPs within the facility(ies)?'

label: NET-16
content:
'Intranets - Mechanisms exist to establish trust relationships with other organizations owning, operating, and/or maintaining intranet systems, allowing authorized individuals to: 
 (1) Access the intranet from external systems; and
 (2) Process, store, and/or transmit organization-controlled information using the external systems.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization establish trust relationships with other organizations owning, operating, and/or maintaining intranet systems, allowing authorized individuals to: 
 (1) Access the intranet from external systems; and
 (2) Process, store, and/or transmit organization-controlled information using the external systems?'

label: NET-17
content: 'Data Loss Prevention (DLP) - Automated mechanisms exist to implement Data Loss Prevention (DLP) to protect sensitive information as it is stored, transmitted and processed.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to implement Data Loss Prevention (DLP) to protect sensitive information as it is stored, transmitted and processed?'

label: NET-18
content: 'DNS & Content Filtering - Mechanisms exist to force Internet-bound network traffic through a proxy device (e.g., Policy Enforcement Point (PEP)) for URL content filtering and DNS filtering to limit a user's ability to connect to dangerous or prohibited Internet sites.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization force Internet-bound network traffic through a proxy device (e.g., Policy Enforcement Point (PEP)) for URL content filtering and DNS filtering to limit a user's ability to connect to dangerous or prohibited Internet sites?'

label: NET-18.1
content: 'Route Internal Traffic to Proxy Servers - Mechanisms exist to route internal communications traffic to external networks through organization-approved proxy servers at managed interfaces.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization route internal communications traffic to external networks through organization-approved proxy servers at managed interfaces?'

label: NET-18.2
content: 'Visibility of Encrypted Communications - Mechanisms exist to configure the proxy to make encrypted communications traffic visible to monitoring tools and mechanisms.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization configure the proxy to make encrypted communications traffic visible to monitoring tools and mechanisms?'

label: NET-18.3
content: 'Route Privileged Network Access - Automated mechanisms exist to route networked, privileged accesses through a dedicated, managed interface for purposes of access control and auditing.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to route networked, privileged accesses through a dedicated, managed interface for purposes of access control and auditing?'

label: NET-18.4
content: 'Protocol Compliance Enforcement - Automated mechanisms exist to ensure network traffic complies with Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) protocol specifications.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to ensure network traffic complies with Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) protocol specifications?'

label: NET-18.5
content: 'Domain Name Verification - Mechanisms exist to ensure that domain name lookups, whether for internal or external domains, are validated according to Domain Name System Security Extensions (DNSSEC).; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization ensure that domain name lookups, whether for internal or external domains, are validated according to Domain Name System Security Extensions (DNSSEC)?'

label: NET-18.6
content: 'Internet Address Denylisting - Mechanisms exist to implement Internet address denylisting protections that blocks traffic received from or destined to a denylisted Internet address.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization implement Internet address denylisting protections that blocks traffic received from or destined to a denylisted Internet address?'

label: NET-18.7
content: 'Bandwidth Control - Mechanisms exist to implement bandwidth control technologies to limit the amount of bandwidth used by categories of domains that are bandwidth-intensive.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization implement bandwidth control technologies to limit the amount of bandwidth used by categories of domains that are bandwidth-intensive?'

label: NET-18.8
content: 'Authenticated Proxy - Mechanisms exist to force systems and processes to authenticate Internet-bound traffic with a proxy to enable user, group and/or location-aware security controls.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization force systems and processes to authenticate Internet-bound traffic with a proxy to enable user, group and/or location-aware security controls?'

label: NET-18.9
content: 'Certificate Denylisting - Mechanisms exist to prevent communication with systems and/or services that use a set of known bad certificates.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization prevent communication with systems and/or services that use a set of known bad certificates?'

label: NET-19
content: 'Content Disarm and Reconstruction (CDR) - Automated Content Disarm and Reconstruction (CDR) mechanisms exist to detect the presence of unapproved active content and facilitate its removal, resulting in content with only known safe elements.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Automated Content Disarm and Reconstruction (CDR) mechanisms exist to detect the presence of unapproved active content and facilitate its removal, resulting in content with only known safe elements?'

label: NET-20
content: 'Email Content Protections - Mechanisms exist to implement an email filtering security service to detect malicious attachments in emails and prevent users from accessing them.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization implement an email filtering security service to detect malicious attachments in emails and prevent users from accessing them?'

label: NET-20.1
content: 'Email Domain Reputation Protections - Mechanisms exist to monitor the organization's email domain’s reputation and protect the email domain’s reputation.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization monitor its email domain’s reputation and protect the email domain’s reputation?'

label: NET-20.2
content: 'Sender Denylisting - Mechanisms exist to implement sender denylisting protections that prevent the reception of email from denylisted senders, domains and/or email servers.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization implement sender denylisting protections that prevent the reception of email from denylisted senders, domains and/or email servers?'

label: NET-20.3
content: 'Authenticated Received Chain (ARC) - Mechanisms exist to utilize an authenticated received chain that allows for an intermediary to sign its own authentication of the original email, allowing downstream entities to accept the intermediary’s authentication even if the email was changed.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization utilize an authenticated received chain that allows for an intermediary to sign its own authentication of the original email, allowing downstream entities to accept the intermediary’s authentication even if the email was changed?'

label: NET-20.4
content:
'Domain-Based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) - Mechanisms exist to implement domain signature verification protections that authenticate incoming email according to the Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance (DMARC).
; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization implement domain signature verification protections that authenticate incoming email according to the Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance (DMARC)?
'

label: NET-20.5
content: 'User Digital Signatures for Outgoing Email - Mechanisms exist to enable users to digitally sign their emails, allowing external parties to authenticate the email’s sender and its contents according to the Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) email authentication protocol.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization enable users to digitally sign their emails, allowing external parties to authenticate the email’s sender and its contents according to the Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) email authentication protocol?'

label: NET-20.6
content: 'Encryption for Outgoing Email - Mechanisms exist to enable the encryption of outgoing emails using organization-approved cryptographic means.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization enable the encryption of outgoing emails using organization-approved cryptographic means?'

label: NET-20.7
content: 'Adaptive Email Protections - Mechanisms exist to utilize adaptive email protections that involve employing risk-based analysis in the application and enforcement of email protections.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization utilize adaptive email protections that involve employing risk-based analysis in the application and enforcement of email protections?'

label: NET-20.8
content: 'Email Labeling - Automated mechanisms exist to implement email labeling that apply organization-defined tags to incoming or outgoing email.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to implement email labeling that apply organization-defined tags to incoming or outgoing email?'

label: NET-20.9
content: 'User Threat Reporting - Mechanisms exist to incorporate submissions from users of phishing attempts, spam or otherwise malicious actions to better protect the organization.; Domain: Network Security; Questions: Does the organization incorporate submissions from users of phishing attempts, spam or otherwise malicious actions to better protect the organization?'

label: OPS-01
content: 'Operations Security - Mechanisms exist to facilitate the implementation of operational security controls.; Domain: Security Operations; Questions: Does the organization facilitate the implementation of operational security controls?'

label: OPS-01.1
content: 'Standardized Operating Procedures (SOP) - Mechanisms exist to identify and document Standardized Operating Procedures (SOP), or similar documentation, to enable the proper execution of day-to-day / assigned tasks.; Domain: Security Operations; Questions: Does the organization identify and document Standardized Operating Procedures (SOP), or similar documentation, to enable the proper execution of day-to-day / assigned tasks?'

label: OPS-02
content: 'Security Concept Of Operations (CONOPS) - Mechanisms exist to develop a security Concept of Operations (CONOPS), or a similarly-defined plan for achieving cybersecurity objectives, that documents management, operational and technical measures implemented to apply defense-in-depth techniques that is communicated to all appropriate stakeholders.; Domain: Security Operations; Questions: Does the organization develop a security Concept of Operations (CONOPS), or a similarly-defined plan for achieving cybersecurity objectives, that documents management, operational and technical measures implemented to apply defense-in-depth techniques that is communicated to all appropriate stakeholders?'

label: OPS-03
content:
'Service Delivery
(Business Process Support)  - Mechanisms exist to define supporting business processes and implement appropriate governance and service management to ensure appropriate planning, delivery and support of the organization's technology capabilities supporting business functions, workforce, and/or customers based on industry-recognized standards to achieve the specific goals of the process area.; Domain: Security Operations; Questions: Does the organization define supporting business processes and implement appropriate governance and service management to ensure appropriate planning, delivery and support of its technology capabilities supporting business functions, workforce, and/or customers based on industry-recognized standards to achieve the specific goals of the process area?'

label: OPS-04
content: 'Security Operations Center (SOC) - Mechanisms exist to establish and maintain a Security Operations Center (SOC) that facilitates a 24x7 response capability.; Domain: Security Operations; Questions: Does the organization establish and maintain a Security Operations Center (SOC) that facilitates a 24x7 response capability?'

label: OPS-05
content: 'Secure Practices Guidelines - Mechanisms exist to provide guidelines and recommendations for the secure use of products and/or services to assist in the configuration, installation and use of the product and/or service.; Domain: Security Operations; Questions: Does the organization provide guidelines and recommendations for the secure use of products and/or services to assist in the configuration, installation and use of the product and/or service?'

label: OPS-06
content: 'Security Orchestration, Automation, and Response (SOAR) - Mechanisms exist to utilize Security Orchestration, Automation and Response (SOAR) tools to define, prioritize and automate the response to security incidents.; Domain: Security Operations; Questions: Does the organization utilize Security Orchestration, Automation and Response (SOAR) tools to define, prioritize and automate the response to security incidents?'

label: OPS-07
content: 'Shadow Information Technology Detection - Mechanisms exist to detect the presence of unauthorized software, systems and services in use.; Domain: Security Operations; Questions: Does the organization detect the presence of unauthorized software, systems and services in use?'

label: PES-01
content: 'Physical & Environmental Protections - Mechanisms exist to facilitate the operation of physical and environmental protection controls.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization facilitate the operation of physical and environmental protection controls?'

label: PES-01.1
content: 'Site Security Plan (SitePlan) - Mechanisms exist to document a Site Security Plan (SitePlan) for each server and communications room to summarize the implemented security controls to protect physical access to technology assets, as well as applicable risks and threats.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization document a Site Security Plan (SitePlan) for each server and communications room to summarize the implemented security controls to protect physical access to technology assets, as well as applicable risks and threats?'

label: PES-01.2
content: 'Zone-Based Physical Security - Mechanisms exist to implement a zone-based approach to physical security.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization implement a zone-based approach to physical security?'

label: PES-02
content: 'Physical Access Authorizations - Physical access control mechanisms exist to maintain a current list of personnel with authorized access to organizational facilities (except for those areas within the facility officially designated as publicly accessible).; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization maintain a current list of personnel with authorized access to organizational facilities (except for those areas within the facility officially designated as publicly accessible)?'

label: PES-02.1
content: 'Role-Based Physical Access - Physical access control mechanisms exist to authorize physical access to facilities based on the position or role of the individual.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization authorize physical access to facilities based on the position or role of the individual?'

label: PES-02.2
content: 'Dual Authorization for Physical Access - Mechanisms exist to enforce a "two-person rule" for physical access by requiring two authorized individuals with separate access cards, keys or PINs, to access highly-sensitive areas (e.g., safe, high-security cage, etc.).; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization enforce a "two-person rule" for physical access by requiring two authorized individuals with separate access cards, keys or PINs, to access highly-sensitive areas (e.g., safe, high-security cage, etc.)?'

label: PES-03
content: 'Physical Access Control - Physical access control mechanisms exist to enforce physical access authorizations for all physical access points (including designated entry/exit points) to facilities (excluding those areas within the facility officially designated as publicly accessible).; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization enforce physical access authorizations for all physical access points (including designated entry/exit points) to facilities (excluding those areas within the facility officially designated as publicly accessible)?'

label: PES-03.1
content: 'Controlled Ingress & Egress Points - Physical access control mechanisms exist to limit and monitor physical access through controlled ingress and egress points.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization limit and monitor physical access through controlled ingress and egress points?'

label: PES-03.2
content: 'Lockable Physical Casings - Physical access control mechanisms exist to protect system components from unauthorized physical access (e.g., lockable physical casings).; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization protect system components from unauthorized physical access (e.g., lockable physical casings)?'

label: PES-03.3
content: 'Physical Access Logs - Physical access control mechanisms generate a log entry for each access attempt through controlled ingress and egress points.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization generate a log entry for each access attempt through controlled ingress and egress points?'

label: PES-03.4
content: 'Access To Information Systems - Physical access control mechanisms exist to enforce physical access to critical information systems or sensitive/regulated data, in addition to the physical access controls for the facility.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization enforce physical access to critical information systems or sensitive/regulated data, in addition to the physical access controls for the facility?'

label: PES-04
content: 'Physical Security of Offices, Rooms & Facilities - Mechanisms exist to identify systems, equipment and respective operating environments that require limited physical access so that appropriate physical access controls are designed and implemented for offices, rooms and facilities.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization identify systems, equipment and respective operating environments that require limited physical access so that appropriate physical access controls are designed and implemented for offices, rooms and facilities?'

label: PES-04.1
content: 'Working in Secure Areas - Physical security mechanisms exist to allow only authorized personnel access to secure areas.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization allow only authorized personnel access to secure areas?'

label: PES-04.2
content: 'Searches - Physical access control mechanisms exist to inspect personnel and their personal effects (e.g., personal property ordinarily worn or carried by the individual, including vehicles) to prevent the unauthorized exfiltration of data and technology assets.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization inspect personnel and their personal effects (e.g., personal property ordinarily worn or carried by the individual, including vehicles) to prevent the unauthorized exfiltration of data and technology assets?'

label: PES-04.3
content: 'Temporary Storage - Physical access control mechanisms exist to temporarily store undelivered packages or deliveries in a dedicated, secure area (e.g., security cage, secure room) that is locked, access-controlled and monitored with surveillance cameras and/or security guards.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization temporarily store undelivered packages or deliveries in a dedicated, secure area (e.g., security cage, secure room) that is locked, access-controlled and monitored with surveillance cameras and/or security guards?'

label: PES-05
content: 'Monitoring Physical Access - Physical access control mechanisms exist to monitor for, detect and respond to physical security incidents.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization monitor for, detect and respond to physical security incidents?'

label: PES-05.1
content: 'Intrusion Alarms / Surveillance Equipment - Physical access control mechanisms exist to monitor physical intrusion alarms and surveillance equipment.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization monitor physical intrusion alarms and surveillance equipment?'

label: PES-05.2
content: 'Monitoring Physical Access To Information Systems - Facility security mechanisms exist to monitor physical access to critical information systems or sensitive/regulated data, in addition to the physical access monitoring of the facility.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization monitor physical access to critical information systems or sensitive/regulated data, in addition to the physical access monitoring of the facility?'

label: PES-06
content: 'Visitor Control - Physical access control mechanisms exist to identify, authorize and monitor visitors before allowing access to the facility (other than areas designated as publicly accessible).; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization identify, authorize and monitor visitors before allowing access to the facility (other than areas designated as publicly accessible)?'

label: PES-06.1
content: 'Distinguish Visitors from On-Site Personnel - Physical access control mechanisms exist to easily distinguish between onsite personnel and visitors, especially in areas where sensitive/regulated data is accessible.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization easily distinguish between onsite personnel and visitors, especially in areas where sensitive/regulated data is accessible?'

label: PES-06.2
content: 'Identification Requirement - Physical access control mechanisms exist to requires at least one (1) form of government-issued or organization-issued photo identification to authenticate individuals before they can gain access to the facility.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization require at least one (1) form of government-issued or organization-issued photo identification to authenticate individuals before they can gain access to the facility?'

label: PES-06.3
content: 'Restrict Unescorted Access - Physical access control mechanisms exist to restrict unescorted access to facilities to personnel with required security clearances, formal access authorizations and validate the need for access.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization restrict unescorted access to facilities to personnel with required security clearances, formal access authorizations and validate the need for access?'

label: PES-06.4
content: 'Automated Records Management & Review - Automated mechanisms exist to facilitate the maintenance and review of visitor access records.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to facilitate the maintenance and review of visitor access records?'

label: PES-06.5
content: 'Minimize Visitor Personal Data (PD) - Mechanisms exist to minimize the collection of Personal Data (PD) contained in visitor access records.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization minimize the collection of Personal Data (PD) contained in visitor access records?'

label: PES-06.6
content: 'Visitor Access Revocation - Mechanisms exist to ensure visitor badges, or other issued identification, are surrendered before visitors leave the facility or are deactivated at a pre-determined time/date of expiration.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization ensure visitor badges, or other issued identification, are surrendered before visitors leave the facility or are deactivated at a pre-determined time/date of expiration?'

label: PES-07
content: 'Supporting Utilities - Facility security mechanisms exist to protect power equipment and power cabling for the system from damage and destruction.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization protect power equipment and power cabling for the system from damage and destruction?'

label: PES-07.1
content: 'Automatic Voltage Controls - Facility security mechanisms exist to utilize automatic voltage controls for critical system components.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization utilize automatic voltage controls for critical system components?'

label: PES-07.2
content:
'Emergency Shutoff - Facility security mechanisms exist to shut off power in emergency situations by:
 (1) Placing emergency shutoff switches or devices in close proximity to systems or system components to facilitate safe and easy access for personnel; and
 (2) Protecting emergency power shutoff capability from unauthorized activation.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization shut off power in emergency situations by:
 (1) Placing emergency shutoff switches or devices in close proximity to systems or system components to facilitate safe and easy access for personnel; and
 (2) Protecting emergency power shutoff capability from unauthorized activation?'

label: PES-07.3
content: 'Emergency Power - Facility security mechanisms exist to supply alternate power, capable of maintaining minimally-required operational capability, in the event of an extended loss of the primary power source.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization supply alternate power, capable of maintaining minimally-required operational capability, in the event of an extended loss of the primary power source?'

label: PES-07.4
content: 'Emergency Lighting - Facility security mechanisms exist to utilize and maintain automatic emergency lighting that activates in the event of a power outage or disruption and that covers emergency exits and evacuation routes within the facility.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization utilize and maintain automatic emergency lighting that activates in the event of a power outage or disruption and that covers emergency exits and evacuation routes within the facility?'

label: PES-07.5
content: 'Water Damage Protection - Facility security mechanisms exist to protect systems from damage resulting from water leakage by providing master shutoff valves that are accessible, working properly and known to key personnel.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization protect systems from damage resulting from water leakage by providing master shutoff valves that are accessible, working properly and known to key personnel?'

label: PES-07.6
content: 'Automation Support for Water Damage Protection - Facility security mechanisms exist to detect the presence of water in the vicinity of critical information systems and alert facility maintenance and IT personnel.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization detect the presence of water in the vicinity of critical information systems and alert facility maintenance and IT personnel?'

label: PES-07.7
content: 'Redundant Cabling - Mechanisms exist to employ redundant power cabling paths that are physically separated to ensure that power continues to flow in the event one of the cables is cut or otherwise damaged.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization employ redundant power cabling paths that are physically separated to ensure that power continues to flow in the event one of the cables is cut or otherwise damaged?'

label: PES-08
content: 'Fire Protection - Facility security mechanisms exist to utilize and maintain fire suppression and detection devices/systems for the system that are supported by an independent energy source.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization utilize and maintain fire suppression and detection devices/systems for the system that are supported by an independent energy source?'

label: PES-08.1
content: 'Fire Detection Devices - Facility security mechanisms exist to utilize and maintain fire detection devices/systems that activate automatically and notify organizational personnel and emergency responders in the event of a fire.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization utilize and maintain fire detection devices/systems that activate automatically and notify organizational personnel and emergency responders in the event of a fire?'

label: PES-08.2
content: 'Fire Suppression Devices - Facility security mechanisms exist to utilize fire suppression devices/systems that provide automatic notification of any activation to organizational personnel and emergency responders.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization utilize fire suppression devices/systems that provide automatic notification of any activation to organizational personnel and emergency responders?'

label: PES-08.3
content: 'Automatic Fire Suppression - Facility security mechanisms exist to employ an automatic fire suppression capability for critical information systems when the facility is not staffed on a continuous basis.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization employ an automatic fire suppression capability for critical information systems when the facility is not staffed on a continuous basis?'

label: PES-09
content: 'Temperature & Humidity Controls - Facility security mechanisms exist to maintain and monitor temperature and humidity levels within the facility.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization maintain and monitor temperature and humidity levels within the facility?'

label: PES-09.1
content: 'Monitoring with Alarms / Notifications - Facility security mechanisms exist to trigger an alarm or notification of temperature and humidity changes that be potentially harmful to personnel or equipment.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization trigger an alarm or notification of temperature and humidity changes that be potentially harmful to personnel or equipment?'

label: PES-10
content: 'Delivery & Removal - Physical security mechanisms exist to isolate information processing facilities from points such as delivery and loading areas and other points to avoid unauthorized access.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization isolate information processing facilities from points such as delivery and loading areas and other points to avoid unauthorized access?'

label: PES-11
content: 'Alternate Work Site - Physical security mechanisms exist to utilize appropriate management, operational and technical controls at alternate work sites.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization utilize appropriate management, operational and technical controls at alternate work sites?'

label: PES-12
content: 'Equipment Siting & Protection - Physical security mechanisms exist to locate system components within the facility to minimize potential damage from physical and environmental hazards and to minimize the opportunity for unauthorized access.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization locate system components within the facility to minimize potential damage from physical and environmental hazards and to minimize the opportunity for unauthorized access?'

label: PES-12.1
content: 'Transmission Medium Security - Physical security mechanisms exist to protect power and telecommunications cabling carrying data or supporting information services from interception, interference or damage.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization protect power and telecommunications cabling carrying data or supporting information services from interception, interference or damage?'

label: PES-12.2
content: 'Access Control for Output Devices - Physical security mechanisms exist to restrict access to printers and other system output devices to prevent unauthorized individuals from obtaining the output.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization restrict access to printers and other system output devices to prevent unauthorized individuals from obtaining the output?'

label: PES-13
content: 'Information Leakage Due To Electromagnetic Signals Emanations - Facility security mechanisms exist to protect the system from information leakage due to electromagnetic signals emanations.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization protect the system from information leakage due to electromagnetic signals emanations?'

label: PES-14
content: 'Asset Monitoring and Tracking - Physical security mechanisms exist to employ asset location technologies that track and monitor the location and movement of organization-defined assets within organization-defined controlled areas.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization employ asset location technologies that track and monitor the location and movement of organization-defined assets within organization-defined controlled areas?'

label: PES-15
content: 'Electromagnetic Pulse (EMP) Protection - Physical security mechanisms exist to employ safeguards against Electromagnetic Pulse (EMP) damage for systems and system components.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization employ safeguards against Electromagnetic Pulse (EMP) damage for systems and system components?'

label: PES-16
content: 'Component Marking - Physical security mechanisms exist to mark system hardware components indicating the impact or classification level of the information permitted to be processed, stored or transmitted by the hardware component.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization mark system hardware components indicating the impact or classification level of the information permitted to be processed, stored or transmitted by the hardware component?'

label: PES-17
content: 'Proximity Sensor - Automated mechanisms exist to monitor physical proximity to robotic or autonomous platforms to reduce applied force or stop the operation when sensors indicate a potentially dangerous scenario.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to monitor physical proximity to robotic or autonomous platforms to reduce applied force or stop the operation when sensors indicate a potentially dangerous scenario?'

label: PES-18
content: 'On-Site Client Segregation - Mechanisms exist to ensure client-specific Intellectual Property (IP) is isolated from other data when client-specific IP is processed or stored within multi-client workspaces.; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization ensure client-specific Intellectual Property (IP) is isolated from other data when client-specific IP is processed or stored within multi-client workspaces?'

label: PES-19
content: 'Physical Access Device Inventories - Mechanisms exist to maintain an accurate inventory of all physical access devices (e.g., RFID cards, access fobs, door keys, etc.).; Domain: Physical & Environmental Security; Questions: Does the organization maintain an accurate inventory of all physical access devices (e.g., RFID cards, access fobs, door keys, etc.)?'

label: PRI-01
content: 'Data Privacy Program - Mechanisms exist to facilitate the implementation and operation of data protection controls throughout the data lifecycle to ensure all forms of Personal Data (PD) are processed lawfully, fairly and transparently.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization facilitate the implementation and operation of data protection controls throughout the data lifecycle to ensure all forms of Personal Data (PD) are processed lawfully, fairly and transparently?'

label: PRI-01.1
content: 'Chief Privacy Officer (CPO) - Mechanisms exist to appoints a Chief Privacy Officer (CPO) or similar role, with the authority, mission, accountability and resources to coordinate, develop and implement, applicable data privacy requirements and manage data privacy risks through the organization-wide data privacy program.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization have a Chief Privacy Officer (CPO) or similar role, with the authority, mission, accountability and resources to coordinate, develop and implement, applicable data privacy requirements and manage data privacy risks through the organization-wide data privacy program?'

label: PRI-01.10
content: 'Financial Incentives For Personal Data (PD) - Mechanisms exist to strictly govern financial incentives offered to data subjects for Personal Data (PD) to ensure compliance with applicable legal and regulatory requirements.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization strictly govern financial incentives offered to data subjects for Personal Data (PD) to ensure compliance with applicable legal and regulatory requirements?'

label: PRI-01.2
PRI-01.3
PRI-01.4
content:
'Data Protection Officer (DPO) - Mechanisms exist to appoint a Data Protection Officer (DPO):
 (1) Based on professional qualifications; and
 (2) To be involved in all issues related to how Personal Data (PD) is collected, received, processed, stored, transmitted and disposed.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization appoint a Data Protection Officer (DPO):
 (1) Based on professional qualifications; and
 (2) To be involved in all issues related to how Personal Data (PD) is collected, received, processed, stored, transmitted and disposed?'

label: PRI-01.5
content: 'Binding Corporate Rules (BCR) - Mechanisms exist to implement and manage Binding Corporate Rules (BCR) (e.g., data sharing agreement) to legally-bind all parties engaged in a joint economic activity that contractually states enforceable rights on data subjects with regard to the processing of their personal data.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization implement and manage Binding Corporate Rules (BCR) (e.g., data sharing agreement) to legally-bind all parties engaged in a joint economic activity that contractually states enforceable rights on data subjects with regard to the processing of their personal data?'

label: PRI-01.6
content: 'Security of Personal Data (PD) - Mechanisms exist to ensure Personal Data (PD) is protected by logical and physical security safeguards that are sufficient and appropriately scoped to protect the confidentiality and integrity of the PD.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization ensure Personal Data (PD) is protected by logical and physical security safeguards that are sufficient and appropriately scoped to protect the confidentiality and integrity of the PD?'

label: PRI-01.7
content: 'Limiting Personal Data (PD) Disclosures - Mechanisms exist to limit the disclosure of Personal Data (PD) to authorized parties for the sole purpose for which the PD was obtained.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization limit the disclosure of Personal Data (PD) to authorized parties for the sole purpose for which the PD was obtained?'

label: PRI-01.8
content:
'Data Fiduciary - Mechanisms exist to appoint an individual to determine the following criteria about Personal Data (PD):
(1) The purpose why PD is necessary; 
(2) Authorized methods to collect, receive, process, store, transmit and dispose PD; and
(3) Authorized parties PD may be shared with.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization appoint an individual to determine the following criteria about Personal Data (PD):
(1) The purpose why PD is necessary; 
(2) Authorized methods to collect, receive, process, store, transmit and dispose PD; and
(3) Authorized parties PD may be shared with?'

label: PRI-01.9
content: 'Personal Data (PD) Process Manager - Mechanisms exist to assign accountability to a Personal Data Process Manager, or equivalent role, to ensure Personal Data (PD) is collected, processed, stored, shared, protected and disposed of according to data subject consent.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization assign accountability to a Personal Data Process Manager, or equivalent role, to ensure Personal Data (PD) is collected, processed, stored, shared, protected and disposed of according to data subject consent?'

label: PRI-02
PRI-02.1
content: 'Purpose Specification - Mechanisms exist to ensure the data privacy notice identifies the purpose(s) for which Personal Data (PD) is collected, received, processed, stored, transmitted, shared.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization ensure the data privacy notice identifies the purpose(s) for which Personal Data (PD) is collected, received, processed, stored, transmitted, shared?'

label: PRI-02.2
content: 'Automated Data Management Processes - Automated mechanisms exist to adjust data that is able to be collected, received, processed, stored, transmitted, shared, based on updated data subject authorization(s).; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to adjust data that is able to be collected, received, processed, stored, transmitted, shared, based on updated data subject authorization(s)?'

label: PRI-02.3
content: 'Computer Matching Agreements (CMA) - Mechanisms exist to publish Computer Matching Agreements (CMA) on the organization's public website(s).; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization publish Computer Matching Agreements (CMA) on its public website(s)?'

label: PRI-02.4
content: 'System of Records Notice (SORN) - Mechanisms exist to draft, publish and keep System of Records Notices (SORN) updated in accordance with regulatory guidance.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization draft, publish and keep System of Records Notices (SORN) updated in accordance with regulatory guidance?'

label: PRI-02.5
content: 'System of Records Notice (SORN) Review Process - Mechanisms exist to review all routine uses of data published in the System of Records Notices (SORN) to ensure continued accuracy and to ensure that routine uses continue to be compatible with the purpose for which the information was collected.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization review all routine uses of data published in the System of Records Notices (SORN) to ensure continued accuracy and to ensure that routine uses continue to be compatible with the purpose for which the information was collected?'

label: PRI-02.6
content: 'Privacy Act Exemptions - Mechanisms exist to review all Privacy Act exemptions claimed for the System of Records Notices (SORN) to ensure they remain appropriate and accurate.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization review all Privacy Act exemptions claimed for the System of Records Notices (SORN) to ensure they remain appropriate and accurate?'

label: PRI-02.7
content: 'Real-Time or Layered Notice - Mechanisms exist to provide real-time and/or layered notice when Personal Data (PD) is collected that provides data subjects with a summary of key points or more detailed information that is specific to the organization's data privacy notice.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization provide real-time and/or layered notice when Personal Data (PD) is collected that provides data subjects with a summary of key points or more detailed information that is specific to its data privacy notice?'

label: PRI-03
content:
'Choice & Consent - Mechanisms exist to enable data subjects to authorize the collection, processing, storage, sharing, updating and disposal of their Personal Data (PD), where prior to collection the data subject is provided with:
 (1) Plain language to illustrate the potential data privacy risks of the authorization; 
 (2) A means for users to decline the authorization; and
 (3) All necessary choice and consent-related criteria required by applicable statutory, regulatory and contractual obligations.
; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization authorize the collection, processing, storage, sharing, updating and disposal of a data subject's Personal Data (PD), where prior to collection the data subject is provided with:
 (1) Plain language to illustrate the potential data privacy risks of the authorization; 
 (2) A means for users to decline the authorization; and
 (3) All necessary choice and consent-related criteria required by applicable statutory, regulatory and contractual obligations?'

label: PRI-03.1
content: 'Tailored Consent - Mechanisms exist to allow data subjects to modify permission to collect, receive, process, store, transmit, update and/or share selected attributes of their Personal Data (PD).; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization allow data subjects to modify permission to collect, receive, process, store, transmit, update and/or share selected attributes of their Personal Data (PD)?'

label: PRI-03.10
content: 'Cease Processing, Storing and/or Sharing Personal Data (PD) - Mechanisms exist to ensure the organization ceases collecting, receiving, processing, storing, transmitting, updating and/or sharing Personal Data (PD) upon receiving a data subject's consent revocation.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization ensure it ceases collecting, receiving, processing, storing, transmitting, updating and/or sharing Personal Data (PD) upon receiving a data subject's consent revocation?'

label: PRI-03.11
content:
'Communicating Processing Changes - Mechanisms exist to notify data subjects of processing changes affecting their Personal Data (PD), including:
 (1) Erasure of PD;
 (2) Remediation of incorrect PD; and/or
 (3) Processing restrictions affecting their PD.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization notify data subjects of processing changes affecting their Personal Data (PD), including:
 (1) Erasure of PD;
 (2) Remediation of incorrect PD; and/or
 (3) Processing restrictions affecting their PD?'

label: PRI-03.2
content:
'Just-In-Time Notice & Updated Consent - Mechanisms exist to present data subjects with a new or updated consent request to process, store and/or share Personal Data (PD) in conjunction with the data action, when:
 (1) The original circumstances under which an individual gave consent have changed; or
 (2) A significant amount of time has passed since an individual gave consent.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization present data subjects with a new or updated consent request to process, store and/or share Personal Data (PD) in conjunction with the data action, when:
 (1) The original circumstances under which an individual gave consent have changed; or
 (2) A significant amount of time has passed since an individual gave consent/'

label: PRI-03.3
content:
'Prohibition of Selling, Processing and/or Sharing Personal Data (PD) - Mechanisms exist to prevent the sale, processing and/or sharing of Personal Data (PD) when:
 (1) Instructed by the data subject; or
 (2) The data subject is a minor, where selling and/or sharing PD is legally prohibited.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization prevent the sale, processing and/or sharing of Personal Data (PD) when:
 (1) Instructed by the data subject; or
 (2) The data subject is a minor, where selling and/or sharing PD is legally prohibited?'

label: PRI-03.4
content: 'Revoke Consent - Mechanisms exist to allow data subjects to revoke consent to collect, receive, process, store, transmit, update and/or share their Personal Data (PD).; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization allow data subjects to revoke consent to collect, receive, process, store, transmit, update and/or share their Personal Data (PD)?'

label: PRI-03.5
content:
'Product or Service Delivery Restrictions - Mechanisms exist to prevent discrimination against a data subject for exercising their legal rights pertaining to modifying or revoking consent, including prohibiting:
 (1) Refusing products and/or services;
 (2) Charging different rates for goods and/or services; and
 (3) Providing different levels of quality.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization prevent discrimination against a data subject for exercising their legal rights pertaining to modifying or revoking consent, including prohibiting:
 (1) Refusing products and/or services;
 (2) Charging different rates for goods and/or services; and
 (3) Providing different levels of quality?'

label: PRI-03.6
content: 'Authorized Agent - Mechanisms exist to allow data subjects to authorize another person or entity, acting on the data subject's behalf, to make Personal Data (PD) processing decisions.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization allow data subjects to authorize another person or entity, acting on the data subject's behalf, to make Personal Data (PD) processing decisions?'

label: PRI-03.7
content: 'Active Participation By Data Subjects - Mechanisms exist to compel data subjects to select the level of consent deemed appropriate by the data subject for the relevant business purpose (e.g., opt-in, opt-out, accept all cookies, etc.).; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization compel data subjects to select the level of consent deemed appropriate by the data subject for the relevant business purpose (e.g., opt-in, opt-out, accept all cookies, etc.)?'

label: PRI-03.8
content: 'Global Privacy Control (GPC) - Automated mechanisms exist to provide data subjects with functionality to exercise pre-selected opt-out preferences (e.g., opt-out signal).; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to provide data subjects with functionality to exercise pre-selected opt-out preferences (e.g., opt-out signal)?'

label: PRI-03.9
content:
'Continued Use of Personal Data (PD) - Mechanisms exist to govern the continued use of Personal Data (PD) as it is collected, received, processed, stored, transmitted and/or shared until:
 (1) Disposal of PD occurs when there is no longer a legitimate business purpose;
 (2) Disposal of PD occurs when the data retention timeline for the use case is met; and/or
 (3) Continued use of PD is prohibited upon withdrawal of data subject consent.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization govern the continued use of Personal Data (PD) as it is collected, received, processed, stored, transmitted and/or shared until:
 (1) Disposal of PD occurs when there is no longer a legitimate business purpose;
 (2) Disposal of PD occurs when the data retention timeline for the use case is met; and/or
 (3) Continued use of PD is prohibited upon withdrawal of data subject consent?'

label: PRI-04
content: 'Restrict Collection To Identified Purpose - Mechanisms exist to minimize the collection of Personal Data (PD) to only what is adequate, relevant and limited to the purposes identified in the data privacy notice, including protections against collecting PD from minors without appropriate parental or legal guardian consent.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization minimize the collection of Personal Data (PD) to only what is adequate, relevant and limited to the purposes identified in the data privacy notice, including protections against collecting PD from minors without appropriate parental or legal guardian consent?'

label: PRI-04.1
content: 'Authority To Collect, Process, Store & Share Personal Data (PD) - Mechanisms exist to determine and document the legal authority that permits the organization to collect, receive, process, store, transmit, update and/or share Personal Data (PD), either generally or in support of a specific business process.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization determine and document the legal authority that permits the organization to collect, receive, process, store, transmit, update and/or share Personal Data (PD), either generally or in support of a specific business process?'

label: PRI-04.2
content: 'Primary Sources - Mechanisms exist to ensure information is directly collected from the data subject, whenever possible.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization ensure information is directly collected from the data subject, whenever possible?'

label: PRI-04.3
content: 'Identifiable Image Collection - Mechanisms exist to restrict collecting, receiving, processing, storing, transmitting and/or sharing of photographic and/or video surveillance image collection that can identify individuals to legitimate business needs.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization restrict collecting, receiving, processing, storing, transmitting and/or sharing of photographic and/or video surveillance image collection that can identify individuals to legitimate business needs?'

label: PRI-04.4
content: 'Acquired Personal Data (PD) - Mechanisms exist to promptly inform data subjects of the utilization purpose when their Personal Data (PD) is acquired and not received directly from the data subject, except where that utilization purpose was disclosed in advance to the data subject.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization promptly inform data subjects of the utilization purpose when their Personal Data (PD) is acquired and not received directly from the data subject, except where that utilization purpose was disclosed in advance to the data subject?'

label: PRI-04.5
content: 'Validate Collected Personal Data (PD) - Mechanisms exist to ensure that the data subject, or authorized representative, validate Personal Data (PD) during the collection process.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization ensure that the data subject, or authorized representative, validate Personal Data (PD) during the collection process?'

label: PRI-04.6
content: 'Re-Validate Collected Personal Data (PD) - Mechanisms exist to ensure that the data subject, or authorized representative, re-validate that Personal Data (PD) acquired during the collection process is still accurate.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization ensure that the data subject, or authorized representative, re-validate that Personal Data (PD) acquired during the collection process is still accurate?'

label: PRI-04.7
PRI-05
content:
'Personal Data (PD) Retention & Disposal - Mechanisms exist to: 
 (1) Retain Personal Data (PD), including metadata, for an organization-defined time period to fulfill the purpose(s) identified in the notice or as required by law;
 (2) Dispose of, destroys, erases, and/or anonymizes the PD, regardless of the method of storage; and
 (3) Use organization-defined techniques or methods to ensure secure deletion or destruction of PD (including originals, copies and archived records).; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization: 
 (1) Retain Personal Data (PD), including metadata, for an organization-defined time period to fulfill the purpose(s) identified in the notice or as required by law;
 (2) Dispose of, destroys, erases, and/or anonymizes the PD, regardless of the method of storage; and
 (3) Use organization-defined techniques or methods to ensure secure deletion or destruction of PD (including originals, copies and archived records)?'

label: PRI-05.1
content:
'Internal Use of Personal Data (PD) For Testing, Training and Research - Mechanisms exist to address the use of Personal Data (PD) for internal testing, training and research that:
 (1) Takes measures to limit or minimize the amount of PD used for internal testing, training and research purposes; and
 (2) Authorizes the use of PD when such information is required for internal testing, training and research.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization address the use of Personal Data (PD) for internal testing, training and research that:
 (1) Takes measures to limit or minimize the amount of PD used for internal testing, training and research purposes; and
 (2) Authorizes the use of PD when such information is required for internal testing, training and research?'

label: PRI-05.2
content:
'Personal Data (PD) Accuracy & Integrity - Mechanisms exist to ensure the accuracy and relevance of Personal Data (PD) throughout the information lifecycle by:
 (1) Keeping PD up-to-date; and 
 (2) Remediating identified inaccuracies, as necessary.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization ensure the accuracy and relevance of Personal Data (PD) throughout the information lifecycle by:
 (1) Keeping PD up-to-date; and 
 (2) Remediating identified inaccuracies, as necessary?'

label: PRI-05.3
content: 'Data Masking - Mechanisms exist to mask sensitive/regulated data through data anonymization, pseudonymization, redaction or de-identification.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization mask sensitive/regulated data through data anonymization, pseudonymization, redaction or de-identification?'

label: PRI-05.4
content:
'Usage Restrictions of Personal Data (PD) - Mechanisms exist to restrict collecting, receiving, processing, storing, transmitting, updating and/or sharing Personal Data (PD) to:
 (1) The purpose(s) originally collected, consistent with the data privacy notice(s);
 (2) What is authorized by the data subject, or authorized agent; and
 (3) What is consistent with applicable laws, regulations and contractual obligations.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization restrict collecting, receiving, processing, storing, transmitting, updating and/or sharing Personal Data (PD) to:
 (1) The purpose(s) originally collected, consistent with the data privacy notice(s);
 (2) What is authorized by the data subject, or authorized agent; and
 (3) What is consistent with applicable laws, regulations and contractual obligations?'

label: PRI-05.5
content: 'Inventory of Personal Data (PD) - Mechanisms exist to establish and maintain a current inventory of all systems, applications and services that collect, receive, process, store, transmit, update and/or share Personal Data (PD).; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization establish and maintain a current inventory of all systems, applications and services that collect, receive, process, store, transmit, update and/or share Personal Data (PD)?'

label: PRI-05.6
content: 'Personal Data (PD) Inventory Automation Support - Automated mechanisms exist to determine if Personal Data (PD) is maintained in electronic form.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization use automated mechanisms to determine if Personal Data (PD) is maintained in electronic form?'

label: PRI-05.7
content: 'Personal Data (PD) Categories - Mechanisms exist to define and implement data handling and protection requirements for specific categories of sensitive Personal Data (PD).; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization define and implement data handling and protection requirements for specific categories of sensitive Personal Data (PD)?'

label: PRI-05.8
content: 'Personal Data (PD) Formats - Mechanisms exist to retain Personal Data (PD) in a format permitting data subject identification for no longer than is necessary for legitimate business purposes.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization retain Personal Data (PD) in a format permitting data subject identification for no longer than is necessary for legitimate business purposes?'

label: PRI-06
PRI-06.1
content:
'Correcting Inaccurate Personal Data (PD) - Mechanisms exist to maintain a process for:
 (1) Data subjects to have inaccurate Personal Data (PD) maintained by the organization corrected or amended; and
 (2) Disseminating corrections or amendments of PD to other authorized users of the PD.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization maintain a process for:
 (1) Data subjects to have inaccurate Personal Data (PD) maintained by the organization corrected or amended; and
 (2) Disseminating corrections or amendments of PD to other authorized users of the PD?'

label: PRI-06.2
content: 'Notice of Correction or Processing Change - Mechanisms exist to notify affected data subjects if their Personal Data (PD) has been corrected or amended.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization notify affected data subjects if their Personal Data (PD) has been corrected or amended?'

label: PRI-06.3
content: 'Appeal Adverse Decision - Mechanisms exist to maintain a process for data subjects to appeal an adverse decision.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization maintain a process for data subjects to appeal an adverse decision?'

label: PRI-06.4
content: 'User Feedback Management - Mechanisms exist to maintain a process to efficiently and effectively respond to complaints, concerns or questions from authenticated data subjects about how the organization collects, receives, processes, stores, transmits, shares, updates and/or disposes of their Personal Data (PD).; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization maintain a process to efficiently and effectively respond to complaints, concerns or questions from authenticated data subjects about how it collects, receives, processes, stores, transmits, shares, updates and/or disposes of their Personal Data (PD)?'

label: PRI-06.5
content: 'Right to Erasure - Mechanisms exist to maintain a process to erase a data subject's Personal Data (PD), in accordance with applicable laws, regulations and contractual obligations pertaining to the retention of their PD.; Domain: Data Privacy; Questions: Does the organization maintain a process to erase a data subject's Personal Data (PD), in accordance with applicable laws, regulations and contractual obligations pertaining to the retention of their PD?'

label: PRI-06.6
